com.busit

Class Connector

  • Object
    • Connector
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ConnectorHelper, IConnector

    public abstract class Connector
extends Object
implements IConnector, ConnectorHelper
    This class is a simple ConnectorHelper implementation of IConnector which should make life easier.

    How to proceed : extend this class and implement the interface you need among Consumer, Producer and Transformer.

      • id

        public String id()
        Description copied from interface: ConnectorHelper
        Returns a unique instance identifier. The instance identifier will always be the same fo the same user instance of the connector. No different instances of any connector will ever have the same identifier.
        Specified by:
        id in interface ConnectorHelper

      • init

        public void init(Map<String,String> config,
        Map<String,Map<String,String>> inputs,
        Map<String,Map<String,String>> outputs)
        Description copied from interface: IConnector
        Step 1. This method is called by the broker in order to initialize this connector instance. You should consider this method as the constructor and you should not perform any process before IConnector.cron(IMessage, String) or IConnector.setInput(IMessage, String) !
        Specified by:
        init in interface IConnector
        Parameters:
        config - the key/value pair of all configuration parameters
        inputs - the list of all input interfaces (see note for format)
        outputs - the list of all output interfaces (see note for format)

      • cron

        public void cron(IMessage message,
        String interfaceId)
        Description copied from interface: IConnector
        Step 2a. This method is called by the broker when an automatic timer occurs as setup by the user. This method is called first in order to prepare required data and then only the corresponding output is considered when calling IConnector.getOutput(String), all other links on other output interfaces are not triggered.
        Specified by:
        cron in interface IConnector
        interfaceId - the name of the output interface to consider

      • setInput

        public void setInput(IMessage message,
            String interfaceId)
        Description copied from interface: IConnector
        Step 2b. This method is called by the broker when a message is sent by the user. This method is called first in order to prepare required data and then all possible output interfaces linked by the user are triggered by calling IConnector.getOutput(String).
        Specified by:
        setInput in interface IConnector
        Parameters:
        message - the encrypted message of the user
        interfaceId - the name of the input interface to consider
        See Also:
        IMessage

      • getOutput

        public IMessage getOutput(String interfaceId)
        Description copied from interface: IConnector
        Step 3. This method is called by the broker in order to retrieve the message to forward to the next linked connector. This method is always called after either IConnector.cron(IMessage, String) or IConnector.setInput(IMessage, String)
        Specified by:
        getOutput in interface IConnector
        Parameters:
        interfaceId - the name of the output interface to consider
        Returns:
        The message with proper content, or null if there is no data.
        See Also:
        IMessage

      • getSampleData

        public IMessage getSampleData(IMessage message,
                     String interfaceId)
        Description copied from interface: IConnector
        This method is called when the user wants to simulate data production in order to test his scenario. This method should return a static hard-coded message. If your connector does not produce any data, just return null. Note that this metod will always be called after IConnector.init(Map, Map, Map) so you can rely on a fully populated configuration.
        Specified by:
        getSampleData in interface IConnector
        Parameters:
        message - an empty template message to fill-in
        interfaceId - the name of the output interface to consider
        Returns:
        The message with proper sample content, or null if there is no data.
        See Also:
        IMessage

      • isFunctional

        public boolean isFunctional(Map<String,String> config,
                   Map<String,Map<String,String>> inputs,
                   Map<String,Map<String,String>> outputs)
                     throws Exception
        Description copied from interface: IConnector
        This method is called internally for time to time in order to test if the conector works. You should build unit tests for your connector in this method and check for external resources or anything you rely on. Note that this method will be called just after the constructor, thus the IConnector.init(Map, Map, Map) method will not be called. Instead, you will be provided the config, inputs and outputs parameters directly. This method is intented to test if your connector works as is, not as part of a scenario. Thus the runtime instance of your implementation is to be considered as an anonymous instance : the config, inputs and outputs will be defaults as you declared them, and not customized by the user. Thus if you rely on OAuth or specific configuration process values or else, those will not be available.
        Specified by:
        isFunctional in interface IConnector
        Parameters:
        config - the key/value pair of all configuration parameters. The value will be null unless you have provided defaults.
        inputs - the list of all input interfaces, the name is the same as the key and the value is null unless you have provided defaults.
        outputs - the list of all output interfaces, the name is the same as the key and the value is null unless you have provided defaults.
        Returns:
        true if the connector should work properly, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        Exception - Any exception is allowed to be thrown and is considered as a failure equivalent to returning false. However, throwing an exception allows to mention a specific cause that will eventually help troubleshooting.
